p: The promotion of European plant derived products (particularly those coming from rural areas), such as, wines and spirits, with specific characteristics determined by the geographical origin, including the area of production, has experienced a significant increase, especially in the last decade (Qin et al., 2012). This reflects the large popularity of these local products, which particularly in Spain benefit from a great acceptance. Some examples of Protected Geographical Indications (PGI) include liquors, such as, “Cantueso alicantino,” “Palo de Mallorca” or “Ratafía catalana”; anise-flavored spirits like “Anís Paloma Monforte del Cid,” “Hierbas Ibicencas” and “Hierbas de Mallorca”; or other alcoholic drinks, such as, “Herbero de la Sierra Mariola,” “Aperitivo Café de Alcoy,” “Aguardiente de hierbas de Galicia,” and “Pacharán de Navarra” (E-Spirits-Drinks, 2017). Many of them are made in the Eastern part of the Iberian Peninsula or in the Balearic Islands as an evolution of traditional herbal preparations, which nowadays have a social use as drinks in family gatherings and festivals.
